text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with cider braised pork cheeks
that's right most people know that cheek
muscles are how we smile but did you
also know that cheek muscles can be a
great reason to smile is hopefully I'm
going to demonstrate with this very
delicious and quite simple recipe and by
the way if the thought of eating and
animals cheeks makes you a little uneasy
it really shouldn't I mean are you
really telling me you would bite into an
animal's ankle or shoulder or butt but
not a cheek that doesn't make any sense
so really the only thing you should be
thinking about is how delicious a piece
of meat this is not to mention easy to
work with so what I have here is 6 pork
cheeks those are going to run about 5
ounces each and then besides the cheek
co-starring in this recipe is this some
Howard cider and I'm going to be using
one from France that runs about 5%
alcohol ensure you go with a
non-alcoholic one it'll work basically
the same but anyway once we have our
cheeks in cider we can start with the
seasoning which will be a generous
application of salt and freshly ground
black pepper on this side we're starting
with sort of looks like it has a silver
skin that you could be inclined to trim
off but don't we're going to want to use
that as is so we will season that up and
then flip these over to what we'll call
the meat side and if you look carefully
you can see sort of white lines a
connective tissue which is one reason
this is such a beautiful cut of meat to
brazzers do so we will thoughtfully
season both sides and yes I was looking
in the viewfinder and never flipped that
last one in other words I failed to turn
the other cheek but anyway once those
are seasoned we'll go ahead and dust
those and flour all over and we're doing
that for two reasons
first of all it's going to give us a
beautiful golden-brown crust when we go
ahead and sear these which is going to
be our next step
but as you'll see that a little bit of
flour is actually going to help thicken
the sauce at the end so we will flour
those up before thoroughly browning
these on both sides and some clarified
butter in a pan set over medium-high
heat and as usual the only way to really
mess up this step is to not brown these
enough so take your time and let these
get a really nice sear on them and I
said use medium-high heat but you may
have to adjust that depending on what
you're seeing in the pan you are after
all the merese of your cheeks
yes I've been watching a lot of
basketball but anyway we're going to
brown those thoroughly on both sides on
about medium-high heat
and hopefully when you're done you
something that looks like this and then
once that's been accomplished we're
going to do a couple things we'll go
ahead and turn our heat down to medium
as well as transfer those Brown pork
cheeks to a plate to rest because what
we want to do next is saute our
vegetables in that pork cheek infused
butter but we only need a couple
tablespoons to do that and as I looked
in this pan I realized I had a little
too much so as you see me do before I
blot it out about half of it with a
paper towel leaving in a couple
tablespoons and if you're wondering why
didn't I just start with less butter
it's not a bad question but I always
like to make sure I have ample fat when
I'm doing that browning step because you
really do get a better sear but either
way we'll go ahead and add our onions
celery and carrots that as you can see
have been diced up along with a generous
pinch of salt and what we want to do and
please stop me if you've heard this one
before is cook that stirring until the
vegetables kind of soften and sweeten up
a little bit and those onions go from
something that's white to something
that's sort of translucent and I can't
tell you exactly how long that's going
to take but it doesn't matter just keep
sauteing them until they look something
like this at which point we can
introduce our liquids the first of which
would be some apple cider vinegar so
we'll throw a splash of that in which of
course is going to deglaze the bottom
and in case you're wondering any vinegar
will work here but we do want a little
bit of acidity to balance the sweetness
of the cider which we will also go ahead
and add at this point and by the way I
cleverly designed this recipe so you
only need half a bottle of cider and
we'll have about half about a left to
drink so we got that going for us which
is nice and then last but not least
we'll add a couple cups of chicken broth
or pork stock if you have it
which you don't and then once our
liquids are in we can bring this up to a
simmer on high heat and while I was
waiting for that to start to bubble I
chopped and added a little bit of too
very pork friendly herbs sage and
rosemary but not too much only about a
teaspoon of each okay we want that herb
to be very subtle and not overpowering
so we'll stir that in at which point we
can transfer our cheeks back into the
pan and we will also need to turn our
heat down to low because what's going to
happen here once these are back in we're
simply going to let it simmer on low
heat for about two to three hours or
until fork-tender and depending on the
exact size and shape your pan as you can
see here some of that meat might be
above the surface but that's not going
to be a problem at all because we're
actually going to
this wild simmers so that me should cook
through regardless but hey if you're
nervous
feel free to uncover that and give those
a turn once a while it's not like it's
going to hurt anything it's just
probably not necessary but anyway like I
said we're going to cook that on low
covered for about two to three hours or
until fork-tender so really it's going
to depend on the size of your Chi as far
as how soon to peak so they're a little
on the smaller side they may be done at
the two-hour mark but mine we're pretty
good-sized so they took more like two
and a half three hours but you'll know
because you're going to stick a fork in
it to test and that fork should go in
without too much effort but we don't
want these falling apart because they
are going to cook for another 15 20
minutes as we finish the sauce okay so I
tested mine and determine they were just
about right
at which point we're going to remove
those from the pan and transfer them
onto a plate and then if you'll indulge
me for a few seconds I don't really do
impressions I'm known more for my lame
jokes and bad puns but I'd like to share
one right now this is my impression of a
food blogger who went to film school
don't worry a couple people got that
joke but anyway we're going to remove
our fork tender cheeks to a plate and
we'll crank our heat back up to high
because what we want to do is reduce
this liquid down to a sauce and as you
all know when something like this boils
in a pan all that extra fat is going to
kind of pull up in the middle which
makes it easy to spoon off and no not
for health reasons I'm doing it because
I don't want that fat coating my palate
as I'm eating the sauce it's going to
block some of the flavor and I do not
like my flavor blocked so I'm going to
skim that off and then what we want to
do here is reduce this by about I don't
know 60 70 percent or so until we have
something that roughly looks like this
right you see how that's just starting
to thicken up a little bit that is
looking pretty good and we're about to
transfer our cheeks back in but before
we do let's go ahead and taste for salt
so I did it might seem like I needed a
little touch so I threw another pinch in
although you should be a little careful
because this is still going to reduce a
little bit but anyway we can do a little
salt adjustment there if we think it
needs it at which point we're going to
transfer our cheeks back in and then as
far as our endgame goes here very very
simple
we're going to let this continue to cook
on about medium-low heat until our pork
cheeks are heated through an absolutely
tender and our sauce is reduced enough
to coat our pork so we'll just let that
simmer uncovered keeping an eye on it
and by the way I have no idea why I'm
basting this I guess I thought it would
look cool you could just simply turn
these over every couple minutes or
better yet do both but anyway like I
said we're going to continue on
medium-low until our sauce seems just
about right and this is what mine look
like when I was just about done see that
sauce is reduced and thickened up enough
to coat that me nicely and by the way if
you just noticed a fairly significant
change in the color and lighting there's
a reason for that
this shot was done 24 hours after the
last shot you just saw so this is
definitely something you can make ahead
and finish off the next day in fact it
might even come out a little better but
either way it's going to be great and I
only mentioned it to explain that little
difference in appearance and once our
sauce is reduced to the perfect
viscosity we're pretty much done except
we will do one last taste for seasoning
and mine was perfect and didn't need
anything but I remembered I hadn't used
cayenne in two videos and some of you
were getting a little antsy so I did add
in stir in a pinch
after a few more seconds of stirring and
basting I was ready to serve up and as
the old saying goes
I put bold cheeks into it and of course
by it I mean a nice bed of buttery
mashed potatoes so we will serve up a
couple of those beautiful clumps of meat
and of course we're going to want to
spoon over plenty of that amazing sauce
and as you know I don't use that term
lightly but this stuff is really truly
amazing and don't worry we're going to
clean those drips up before the next
shot there we go and we could stop right
there but I did have a few chives around
so I finished up with a little bit of
that and that's it our cider braised
pork cheeks are done and that my friends
is just one spectacular plate of
slow-cooked meaty goodness and if you've
never had this before you may think it's
similar to like a stewed pork shoulder
but believe it or not it's actually much
closer in flavor and texture to a beef
pot roast although maybe even a little
richer than that and by the way we use
cider this time but these pork cheeks
will work in pretty much any stewed or
braised recipe so while it's a little
bit unusual I really love this cut of
meat and know this is not something
you're going to see sitting in the meat
case at the grocery store you're
actually going to go have to order some
from a real butcher but they are really
not that hard to find which is why I'm
really hoping sometime very soon these
cheeks meet your cheeks alright
so head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
you
